intro: Gasteranthus sylvarum, commonly known as the "Cupflower," is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is native to the humid forests of South America. It is characterized by its striking, cup-shaped flowers that are often brightly colored, typically in shades of red or orange. The plant produces small, fleshy fruits that contain a single seed, which is dispersed by animals. Gasteranthus sylvarum thrives in shaded, moist environments and is often found in the understory of tropical rainforests. Its unique floral structure and ecological role make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
